In 1858, visiting the Gros Ventre tribe, Pine Leaf was ambushed and killed by Gros Ventre warriors.

TEXT.English: The [OUR_CIV_ADJ] welcome the bearded visitors to their camps. We are a peaceful people, and if you treat us honorably, you will enjoy our enduring friendship. My name is [OUR_NAME], war chief of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Let us share the songs of our ancestors at the communal fire tonight.
TEXT.French: Les [OUR_CIV_ADJ] vous souhaite la bienvenue dans ses campements. Mon nom est [OUR_NAME], chef guerrière et membre du Conseil des tribus [OUR_CIV_ADJ:3].
TEXT.German: Fremder, ich bin [OUR_NAME], Oberhaupt der Crow. Wärmt euch an unseren Feuern, doch achtet die Regeln der Gastfreundschaft.
TEXT.Italian: Salve. Mi chiamo [OUR_NAME], capo e protettore del popolo [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Ti considero un amico. È nel tuo migliore interesse che io non cambi mai idea.
TEXT.Spanish: Hola. Soy [OUR_NAME], jefe y protector del pueblo [OUR_CIV_ADJ:1]. Os considero mis amigos. Y más os vale que nunca cambie de opinión.

TEXT.English: Your past treacheries have filled the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] with a great sadness. We do not want to speak with you anymore.
TEXT.French: Vos trahisons passées ont rempli de déception le coeur des [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Nous ne voulons plus vous parler.
TEXT.German: Ihr wollt reden, [CT_NAME]? Nein. Handelt lieber und verschwindet aus dieser Welt.
TEXT.Italian: Vuoi parlare? È un po' troppo tardi per farlo.
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Ahora queréis hablar? Es un poco tarde para eso.

TEXT.English: There is nothing to be gained by making peace with you again. We will drive you off the cliffs of this life like bisons.
TEXT.French: La paix avec vous ne nous apporterait rien. Nous vous jeterons de la falaise comme un vulgaire troupeau de bisons.
TEXT.German: Nein, Frieden kann es zwischen uns nach euren Taten nicht mehr geben.
TEXT.Italian: Pace? Mai!
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Paz? ¡Jamás!

TEXT.English: I have always time to speak with my good friends of the [CT_EMPIRE]. How can the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] aid you?
TEXT.French: J'ai toujours le temps qu'il faut pour parler à mes amis de l'[CT_EMPIRE]. En quoi les [OUR_CIV_ADJ] peuvent-ils vous aider ?
TEXT.German: Nehmt Platz am Feuer, Freund. Auch wenn Ihr es an Weisheit nicht mit der großen Pine Leaf aufnehmen könnt, so begegnen wir Euch doch mit Respekt.
TEXT.Italian: È bello avere notizie da [CT_EMPIRE]. A cosa debbo quest'onore?
TEXT.Spanish: Es un placer oír al [CT_EMPIRE]. ¿A qué debo este honor?

TEXT.English: I'm sorry to inform you that the [CT_CIV_ADJ] are not welcome visitors to our lands, as the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] are greatly troubled by your actions of late. Why do you disturb our peace?
TEXT.French: J'ai le regret de vous annoncer que les [CT_CIV_ADJ] ne sont plus la bienvenue dans nos plaines. Pourquoi vous ne nous laissez pas tranquille ?
TEXT.German: Der Große Kriegsrat unseres Bundes berät bereits über Euer weiteres Schicksal, [CT_NAME]. Fügt Euch seinem weisen Ratschluss, und Ihr werdet im Augenblick Eures Todes mehr Würde zeigen als in Eurem ganzen Leben zuvor.
TEXT.Italian: Ti sei avviato lungo un cammino che porterà alla tua distruzione. Prova pure a cercare di spiegarti.
TEXT.Spanish: Habéis hollado una senda que os llevará a la destrucción. Intentad explicaros como queráis.

TEXT.English: My tribe is in need, will the [CT_EMPIRE] prove true friends and help?
TEXT.French: Ma tribu est dans le besoin, l'[CT_EMPIRE] peut-il nous aider ?
TEXT.German: Mein Stamm ist in Not. Teilt Eure Vorräte mit uns, weißer Mann, und unsere Enkel werden ihren Enkeln von Euren milden Taten Geschichten erzählen.
TEXT.Italian: La mia tribù ha bisogno di aiuto, potete aiutarci?
TEXT.Spanish: Mi tribu está necesitada. ¿Podrá ayudarnos el [CT_EMPIRE]?

TEXT.English: I come in peace to ask for assistance. What do you say?
TEXT.French: Je suis venu en paix vous demander de l'aide. Qu'avez-vous à répondre ?
TEXT.German: Ich komme in Frieden und bitte um Unterstützung. Wie lautet Eure Antwort?
TEXT.Italian: Vengo in pace alla ricerca di aiuto. Cosa mi rispondi?
TEXT.Spanish: Vengo en son de paz a pedir ayuda. ¿Qué me decís?

TEXT.English: I could wipe the seed of the [CT_EMPIRE] from this land at will. Give me what I demand and I may allow you to live a while longer.
TEXT.French: Je tiens le destin de l'[CT_EMPIRE] dans ma main. Donnez-moi ce que j'exige.
TEXT.German: Ich halte Euer Schicksal in meinen Händen. Gebt mir, was ich verlange.
TEXT.Italian: Ho nelle mani il destino di [CT_EMPIRE]. Dammi ciò che chiedo.
TEXT.Spanish: Tengo el destino del [CT_EMPIRE] en mis manos. Dadme lo que os exijo.

TEXT.English: Blackfoot
TEXT.German: Blackfoot:Blackfoot:Blackfoot

TEXT.English: Blackfoot
TEXT.German: Blackfoot

TEXT.English: [TAB] The Blackfoot Confederacy or Niitsitapi (meaning original people) consists of the North Peigan, South Peigan, Kainai Nation and the Siksika Nation, though only the Siksika are known as the Blackfoot, the name allegedly coming from the black dyed soles of their moccasins. [PARAGRAPH:1] Introduced to horses in the first decades of the 18th century, the Blackfoot quickly adopted a life on horseback and began to drive the hostile Shoshone and Arapaho from the Northwestern Plains in order to secure an adequate supply of the animal, often engaging in horse raiding parties against neighboring tribes. By the middle of the 18th century they had made contact with Europeans from Hudson's Bay Company, and in 1806 made their first recorded meeting with European Americans when they encountered the Lewis and Clark expedition. [PARAGRAPH:1] Smallpox epidemics depopulated the tribe through the 1800's, during the 1837 epidemic alone, approximately 6,000 members of the tribe died. Weakened by such epidemics, the Blackfoot were unable to prevent the increasing numbers of white settlers encroaching upon their lands and decimating the bison population, their primary food source. Facing a dwindling food supply the Blackfoot signed the Lame Bull Treaty of 1855 with the United States, which promised the Blackfoot 20,000 Dollar annually in goods and services on the condition that much of their territory become a common hunting grounds for other neighboring tribes and that whites be allowed to settle within Blackfoot lands. The last decades of the 19th century witnessed the further decline of the Blackfoot as their population continued to fall, and their lands were further reduced without approval or consultation by the United States. By the 1880's only the Pikuni remained in Montana, with the Kainai, Siksika, and Piegan moving to Canada in the hopes of receiving fairer treatment and preserving their culture.
TEXT.French: [TAB]La Confédération des Pieds-Noirs, également connue sous le nom anglais de Blackfoot Confederacy, comprend trois tribus nord-amérindiennes des Grandes Plaines de l'Alberta au Canada et du Montana aux États-Unis : les Siksikas, les Pikunis et les Gens-du-Sang. Dans leur propre langue, le pied-noir, ils se nomment Niitsítapi (« le peuple originel »). Ces trois nations partagent depuis plusieurs siècles de nombreuses caractéristiques linguistiques, socio-culturelles et économiques. Ils sont traditionnellement des chasseurs de bison, comme les autres Indiens des Plaines, et ils ont longtemps été considérés comme de redoutables guerriers. Ensemble, ils forment une confédération politique, parfois étendue aux tribus des Tsuu T'ina et des Atsinas. Depuis le XIXe siècle, ils vivent principalement dans quatre réserves, trois au Canada et une aux États-Unis, et leur population totale est de plus de 49 500 individus en 2013.
TEXT.German: [TAB] Die Blackfoot Konföderation besteht aus den Nord-Peigan, Süd-Peigan, der Kainai Nation und der Siksika Nation, obwohl eigentlich nur die Siksika als Blackfoot bekannt sind, was sich angeblich von der schwarzen Sohle ihrer Mokasins ableitete. [PARAGRAPH:1] Nach der ersten Begegnung mit Pferden in den ersten Dekaden des 18ten Jahrhunderts, übernahmen die Blackfoot schnell ein Leben auf dem Pferderücken und begannen die feindlichen Shoshone und Arapaho von den nordwestlichen Ebenen zu verdrängen um sich eine adequate Versorgung mit Pferden zu sichern. Oft brachen sie zu Angriffen auf um Pferde von den benachbarten Stämmen zu stehlen. Mitte des 18ten Jahrhunderts hatten sie Europäer der Hudson's Bay Company getroffen. 1806 fand das erste aufgezeichnete Treffen mit Amerikanern statt, als sie auf die Expedition von Lewis and Clark trafen. [PARAGRAPH:1] Pcken-Epidemien entvölkerten den Stamm um nach 1800. Alleine die Epidemie 1837 tötete ungefährt 6000 Mitglieder des Stammes. Durch solche Ereignisse geschwächt konnten die Blackfoot gegen die wachsende Zahl der weissen Siedler auf ihrem Land und die Dezimierung der Bison Herden, ihre primäre Nahrungsquelle, kaum noch etwas unternehmen. Im Angesicht der schwindenden Nahrungsversorgung unterzeichneten die Blackfoot den Lame Bull Vertrag von 1855 mit den United States, der den Blackfoot 20.000 Dollar jährlich in Gütern und Dienstleistungen versprach, jedoch unter den Bedingungen, dass ihr Territorium als gemeinsames Jagdgebiet mit den benachbarten Stämmen dienen sollte und dass die Weissen Männer auf Blackfoot Land siedeln durfen. Die letzten Dekaden des 19ten Jahrhunderts bezeugten den fortschreitenden Niedergan der Blackfoot. Um 1880 waren nur noch die Pikuni in Montana geblieben und die Kainai, Siksika, und Piegan nach Kanada geflohen. Dort hofften sie auf bessere Behandlung und eine Möglichkeit ihre Kultur und Lebensart zu erhalten.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB] The Blackfoot Confederacy or Niitsitapi (meaning original people) consists of the North Peigan, South Peigan, Kainai Nation and the Siksika Nation, though only the Siksika are known as the Blackfoot, the name allegedly coming from the black dyed soles of their moccasins. [PARAGRAPH:1] Introduced to horses in the first decades of the 18th century, the Blackfoot quickly adopted a life on horseback and began to drive the hostile Shoshone and Arapaho from the Northwestern Plains in order to secure an adequate supply of the animal, often engaging in horse raiding parties against neighboring tribes. By the middle of the 18th century they had made contact with Europeans from Hudson's Bay Company, and in 1806 made their first recorded meeting with European Americans when they encountered the Lewis and Clark expedition. [PARAGRAPH:1] Smallpox epidemics depopulated the tribe through the 1800's, during the 1837 epidemic alone, approximately 6,000 members of the tribe died. Weakened by such epidemics, the Blackfoot were unable to prevent the increasing numbers of white settlers encroaching upon their lands and decimating the bison population, their primary food source. Facing a dwindling food supply the Blackfoot signed the Lame Bull Treaty of 1855 with the United States, which promised the Blackfoot 20,000 Dollar annually in goods and services on the condition that much of their territory become a common hunting grounds for other neighboring tribes and that whites be allowed to settle within Blackfoot lands. The last decades of the 19th century witnessed the further decline of the Blackfoot as their population continued to fall, and their lands were further reduced without approval or consultation by the United States. By the 1880's only the Pikuni remained in Montana, with the Kainai, Siksika, and Piegan moving to Canada in the hopes of receiving fairer treatment and preserving their culture.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB] The Blackfoot Confederacy or Niitsitapi (meaning original people) consists of the North Peigan, South Peigan, Kainai Nation and the Siksika Nation, though only the Siksika are known as the Blackfoot, the name allegedly coming from the black dyed soles of their moccasins. [PARAGRAPH:1] Introduced to horses in the first decades of the 18th century, the Blackfoot quickly adopted a life on horseback and began to drive the hostile Shoshone and Arapaho from the Northwestern Plains in order to secure an adequate supply of the animal, often engaging in horse raiding parties against neighboring tribes. By the middle of the 18th century they had made contact with Europeans from Hudson's Bay Company, and in 1806 made their first recorded meeting with European Americans when they encountered the Lewis and Clark expedition. [PARAGRAPH:1] Smallpox epidemics depopulated the tribe through the 1800's, during the 1837 epidemic alone, approximately 6,000 members of the tribe died. Weakened by such epidemics, the Blackfoot were unable to prevent the increasing numbers of white settlers encroaching upon their lands and decimating the bison population, their primary food source. Facing a dwindling food supply the Blackfoot signed the Lame Bull Treaty of 1855 with the United States, which promised the Blackfoot 20,000 Dollar annually in goods and services on the condition that much of their territory become a common hunting grounds for other neighboring tribes and that whites be allowed to settle within Blackfoot lands. The last decades of the 19th century witnessed the further decline of the Blackfoot as their population continued to fall, and their lands were further reduced without approval or consultation by the United States. By the 1880's only the Pikuni remained in Montana, with the Kainai, Siksika, and Piegan moving to Canada in the hopes of receiving fairer treatment and preserving their culture.

TEXT.English: Blackfoot
TEXT.German: Blackfoot:Blackfoot:Blackfoot:Blackfoot
TEXT.Italian: Blackfoot
TEXT.Spanish: Blackfoot

TEXT.English: Running Eagle

[H1]Running Eagle[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]War Chief of the Blackfoot[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]1815?-1850?[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Little is known of Running Eagle's life. Even the year of her death is unknown, ranging from 1836-1850. Originally known as Brown Weasel Woman, Running Eagle showed a strong talent for hunting and riding from an early age. When she was 15, she accompanied her father on a hunting party, and rescued him from capture after his horse had been shot by an enemy tribe. Her first war experience was against the Crow, whom had stolen several horses from her village. Running Eagle followed the Crow raiding party back to their camp and attacked two enemy of riders, killing one and reclaiming 11 of the stolen horses.[PARAGRAPH:1] Undergoing a vision quest to learn her destiny, Running Eagle received a vision that she was to be a powerful warrior within her tribe. She subsequently took part in and led many war parties, her bravery earning her the name Running Eagle and a place in the warrior society as a war chief. She and five of her warriors were eventually ambushed and clubbed to death by members of the Flathead tribe while trying to steal their horses during a battle.
TEXT.French: [H1]Running Eagle[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Chef guerrière des Pieds-Noirs[NEWLINE]Dates : [\BOLD]env. 1815-env. 1850[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Biographie :[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Nous en savons très peu sur la vie de Running Eagle (ou Aigle Courant), même l'année précise de sa mort, estimée entre 1836 et 1850, est inconnue. D'abord connu sous le nom de Brown Weasel Woman (femme belette brune), Running Eagle démontra très tôt ses talents en équitation et à la chasse. Lorsqu'elle avait 15 ans, elle accompagna son père à une partie de chasse, et viendra à son secours alors que son cheval avait été abattu par une tribu ennemi. Sa première expérience de guerre était contre les Crows, qui avaient volé les chevaux de son village. Running Eagle a pourchassé les fautifs et a ramené d'eux d'entre eux à son campement : elle tua l'un d'entre eux et obtenu le retour de 11 des chevaux volés. [PARAGRAPH:1] Un jour, Running Eagle reçut la vision qu'elle était destinée à devenir un guerrier redoutable de sa tribu. Elle prendra alors part à de nombreux conflits. Son courage lui valu le surnom de Running Eagle, ou Aigle Courant, et le respect de ses pairs. Alors qu'elles cherchaient à voler les cheveaux de Têtes-Plates, elle fut finalement prise dans une embuscade avec cinq de ses guerriers puis battue à mort.
TEXT.German: [H1]Running Eagle[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Kriegshäuptling der Blackfoot[NEWLINE]Lebte: [\BOLD]ca. 1815-1850[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Wenig ist über das Leben von Running Eagle bekannt. Sogar das Jahr ihres Todes kann lediglich zwischen 1836 und 1850 geschätzt werden. Ursprünglich als Brown Weasel Woman bekannt, zeigte Running Eagle bereits in jungen Jahren ein herausragendes Talent für die Jagd und die Reiterei. Mit 15 begleitete sie ihren Vater bereits auf Jagdausflügen und rettete ihn eines Tages sogar vor der Gefangennahme als sein Pferd von einem feindlichen Stamm erschossen wurde. Ihre ersten Kriegserfahrungen sammelte sie gegen die Crow, als diese mehrere Pferde ihres Stammes gestohlen hatten. Running Eagle verfolgte die Gruppe der Crow bis zu ihrem Lager und griff zweig zwei berittene Feinde gleichzeitig an, von denen sie dann einen tötete. 11 Pferde konnten wiedererlangt werden.[PARAGRAPH:1] Bei einer Visionsprüfung um mehr über ihre Zukunft zu erfahren, erhielt Running Eagle eine Vision, dass sie einst der mächtigste Krieger ihres Stamems werden sollte. Sie beteiligte sich an vielen Kriegsgruppen und erlangte so ihren Namen Running Eagle und eines Platz in der Kriergergesellschaft und letztlich sogar den Titel des Kriegshäuptlings. Sie und 5 weitere ihrer Krieger wurden aber in einen Hinterhalt gelockt und zu Tode geknüppelt, als sie die Pferde eines der Flachlandstämme stehlen wollten.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Running Eagle[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]War Chief of the Blackfoot[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]1815?-1850?[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Little is known of Running Eagle's life. Even the year of her death is unknown, ranging from 1836-1850. Originally known as Brown Weasel Woman, Running Eagle showed a strong talent for hunting and riding from an early age. When she was 15, she accompanied her father on a hunting party, and rescued him from capture after his horse had been shot by an enemy tribe. Her first war experience was against the Crow, whom had stolen several horses from her village. Running Eagle followed the Crow raiding party back to their camp and attacked two enemy of riders, killing one and reclaiming 11 of the stolen horses.[PARAGRAPH:1] Undergoing a vision quest to learn her destiny, Running Eagle received a vision that she was to be a powerful warrior within her tribe. She subsequently took part in and led many war parties, her bravery earning her the name Running Eagle and a place in the warrior society as a war chief. She and five of her warriors were eventually ambushed and clubbed to death by members of the Flathead tribe while trying to steal their horses during a battle.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Running Eagle[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]War Chief of the Blackfoot[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]1815?-1850?[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Little is known of Running Eagle's life. Even the year of her death is unknown, ranging from 1836-1850. Originally known as Brown Weasel Woman, Running Eagle showed a strong talent for hunting and riding from an early age. When she was 15, she accompanied her father on a hunting party, and rescued him from capture after his horse had been shot by an enemy tribe. Her first war experience was against the Crow, whom had stolen several horses from her village. Running Eagle followed the Crow raiding party back to their camp and attacked two enemy of riders, killing one and reclaiming 11 of the stolen horses.[PARAGRAPH:1] Undergoing a vision quest to learn her destiny, Running Eagle received a vision that she was to be a powerful warrior within her tribe. She subsequently took part in and led many war parties, her bravery earning her the name Running Eagle and a place in the warrior society as a war chief. She and five of her warriors were eventually ambushed and clubbed to death by members of the Flathead tribe while trying to steal their horses during a battle.

TEXT.English: Welcome, stranger, to the lands of the mighty [OUR_CIV_ADJ] Confederacy. My name is [OUR_NAME], and I hope we can welcome you as a friend, for the legendary warriors of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] are fearsome foes. Let us ask the medicine men to grant our friendship the blessings of the spirits.
TEXT.French: Bienvenue, étranger, dans le pays de la puissante confédération [OUR_CIV_ADJ:2]. Mon nom est [OUR_NAME]. J'espère que nous pouvons vous accueillir en ami, ou sinon vous saurez rapidement pourquoi nos guerriers sont si légendaires.
TEXT.German: Fremder, ich bin [OUR_NAME], Oberhaupt der Blackfoot. Wärmt euch an unseren Feuern, doch achtet die Regeln der Gastfreundschaft.
TEXT.Italian: Salve. Mi chiamo [OUR_NAME], capo e protettore del popolo [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Ti considero un amico. È nel tuo migliore interesse che io non cambi mai idea.
TEXT.Spanish: Hola. Soy [OUR_NAME], jefe y protector del pueblo [OUR_CIV_ADJ:1]. Os considero mis amigos. Y más os vale que nunca cambie de opinión.

TEXT.English: Listening to your words has been my greatest mistake in the past. I never make the same mistake twice.
TEXT.French: Ecouter vos paroles a été ma plus grande faute par le passé. Je ne fais jamais deux fois la même erreur.
TEXT.German: Ihr wollt reden, [CT_NAME]? Nein. Handelt lieber und verschwindet aus dieser Welt.
TEXT.Italian: Vuoi parlare? È un po' troppo tardi per farlo.
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Ahora queréis hablar? Es un poco tarde para eso.

TEXT.English: We will have peace the day I wear your skin as a cloak!
TEXT.French: Il n'y aura la paix que lorsque j'aurais votre scalp en trophée !
TEXT.German: Nein, Frieden kann es zwischen uns nach euren Taten nicht mehr geben.
TEXT.Italian: Pace? Mai!
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Paz? ¡Jamás!

TEXT.English: Welcome to my teepee, friend. Let us have pow wow and speak of our great feats in battle.
TEXT.French: Bienvenue dans mon tipi, cher ami. Faisons donc un Pow Wow et remémorons-nous nos plus grands succès guerriers.
TEXT.German: Nehmt Platz am Feuer, Freund. Auch wenn Ihr es an Weisheit nicht mit der großen Running Eagle aufnehmen könnt, so begegnen wir Euch doch mit Respekt.
TEXT.Italian: È bello avere notizie da [CT_EMPIRE]. A cosa debbo quest'onore?
TEXT.Spanish: Es un placer oír al [CT_EMPIRE]. ¿A qué debo este honor?

TEXT.English: Oh, it's you again. I was already starting to wonder what made the children cry. What foolishness have you devised this time to annoy the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] with?
TEXT.French: Ah tiens ? Vous encore ? Je me demandais pourquoi les enfants pleuraient, j'ai maintenant la réponse. Quelle absurdité allez-vous encore nous proposer ?
TEXT.German: Der Große Kriegsrat unseres Volkes berät bereits über Euer weiteres Schicksal, [CT_NAME]. Fügt Euch seinem weisen Ratschluss, und Ihr werdet im Augenblick Eures Todes mehr Würde zeigen als in Eurem ganzen Leben zuvor.
TEXT.Italian: Ti sei avviato lungo un cammino che porterà alla tua distruzione. Prova pure a cercare di spiegarti.
TEXT.Spanish: Habéis hollado una senda que os llevará a la destrucción. Intentad explicaros como queráis.

TEXT.English: My tribe is in need, will the [CT_EMPIRE] prove true friends and help?
TEXT.French: Ma tribu est dans le besoin, l'[CT_EMPIRE] peut-il nous aider ?
TEXT.German: Mein Stamm ist in Not. Teilt Eure Vorräte mit uns, weißer Mann, und unsere Enkel werden ihren Enkeln von Euren milden Taten Geschichten erzählen.
TEXT.Italian: La mia tribù ha bisogno di aiuto, potete aiutarci?
TEXT.Spanish: Mi tribu está necesitada. ¿Podrá ayudarnos el [CT_EMPIRE]?

TEXT.English: I come in peace to ask for assistance. What do you say?
TEXT.French: Je suis venu en paix vous demander de l'aide. Qu'avez-vous à répondre ?
TEXT.German: Ich komme in Frieden und bitte um Unterstützung. Wie lautet Eure Antwort?
TEXT.Italian: Vengo in pace alla ricerca di aiuto. Cosa mi rispondi?
TEXT.Spanish: Vengo en son de paz a pedir ayuda. ¿Qué me decís?

TEXT.English: I could wipe the seed of the [CT_EMPIRE] from this land at will. Give me what I demand and I may allow you to live a while longer.
TEXT.French: Je tiens le destin de l'[CT_EMPIRE] dans ma main. Donnez-moi ce que j'exige.
TEXT.German: Ich halte Euer Schicksal in meinen Händen. Gebt mir, was ich verlange.
TEXT.Italian: Ho nelle mani il destino di [CT_EMPIRE]. Dammi ciò che chiedo.
TEXT.Spanish: Tengo el destino del [CT_EMPIRE] en mis manos. Dadme lo que os exijo.

TEXT.English: Guaymi
TEXT.German: Guaymi:Guaymi:Guaymi

TEXT.English: Guaymi
TEXT.German: Guaymi

TEXT.English: [TAB] The Guaymi Indians were traditionally located in the remote regions of Bocas Del Toro, Chiriqui and Veraguas. Their territory was divided by the Cordillera Central mountain range of modern day Panama and Costa Rico, resulting in the Guaymi being divided between two areas that were climatically and ecologically different. The Guaymi on the Pacific side of the range found themselves scattered throughout small hamlets in remote regions, whereas the Guaymi on the Atlantic side remained in more populated coastal regions. [PARAGRAPH:1] The Spanish first contacted the Guaymi in the early 1500's but attempts to subdue and conquer them largely failed. After a period of armed conflict, Spanish policy resorted to trying to group the Guaymi into settlements controlled by missions. This policy enjoyed only limited success. Some Indians did convert to Christianity and eventually merged with the growing Metiszo community, but most Guaymi retreated further into the remoteness of the mountain rainforests.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Les Guaymí sont le plus grand groupe indigène du Panama. Ils vivaient traditionnellement dans les provinces de l'Ouest étant la province de Bocas del Toro, la province de Chiriquí et la province de Veraguas. Beaucoup d'ils vivent dans la réserve de Ngöbe-Buglé. Beaucoup d'entre eux ont déménagé. Traditionnellement, ils vivaient dans la jungle. [PARAGRAPH:1] Cerro Colorado est un projet d'exploitation minière qui mette ces terres ancestrales en péril et les a incités à s'organiser politiquement. Dans le cadre du projet des barrages hydroélectrique de Chan 75, des territores des Guaymí seraient inondées. [PARAGRAPH:1] Leur scolarité tend à être relativement faible. Le travail des enfants est fréquent. Le projet hydroélectrique de Barro Blanco mette en péril des territoires Guaymí.
TEXT.German: [TAB] Die Guaymi Indianer waren traditionell in den entlegenen Gegenden von Bocas Del Toro, Chiriqui und Veraguas beheimatet. Ihr Territorium war unterteilt durch die Cordillera Zentralgebirgskette des heutigen Panama und Costa Rico, was dazu führte, dass die Guaymi auf zwei sehr unterschiedliche klimatischen und ökologische Gebiete verteilt waren. Die Guaymi auf der Pazifikseite der Gebirgskette lebten verteilt und abgeschieden, wohingegen die Guaymi auf der Atlantikseite der Gebirgskette in vergleichsweise bevölkerungsreichen Gebieten lebten.[PARAGRAPH:1] Die Spanier erlangten den ersten Kontakt mit den Guaymi in den frühen 1500ern aber Versuche sie zu unterwerfen oder zu erobern blieben erfolglos. Nach einer Periode des bewaffneten Konflikts versuchten die Spaniern die Guaymi zu bewegen in grösseren Siedlungen zu leben, die durch Missionen kontrolliert wurden. Aber auch diese Vorgehen war nur wenig erfolgreich. Einige Indianer konvertierten zwar zum Christentum und verschmolzen letztlich auch mit den spanischen Kolonisten, die meisten Guaymi zogen sich aber weiter in die Abgeschiedenheit des Regenwaldes zurück.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB] The Guaymi Indians were traditionally located in the remote regions of Bocas Del Toro, Chiriqui and Veraguas. Their territory was divided by the Cordillera Central mountain range of modern day Panama and Costa Rico, resulting in the Guaymi being divided between two areas that were climatically and ecologically different. The Guaymi on the Pacific side of the range found themselves scattered throughout small hamlets in remote regions, whereas the Guaymi on the Atlantic side remained in more populated coastal regions. [PARAGRAPH:1] The Spanish first contacted the Guaymi in the early 1500's but attempts to subdue and conquer them largely failed. After a period of armed conflict, Spanish policy resorted to trying to group the Guaymi into settlements controlled by missions. This policy enjoyed only limited success. Some Indians did convert to Christianity and eventually merged with the growing Metiszo community, but most Guaymi retreated further into the remoteness of the mountain rainforests.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB] The Guaymi Indians were traditionally located in the remote regions of Bocas Del Toro, Chiriqui and Veraguas. Their territory was divided by the Cordillera Central mountain range of modern day Panama and Costa Rico, resulting in the Guaymi being divided between two areas that were climatically and ecologically different. The Guaymi on the Pacific side of the range found themselves scattered throughout small hamlets in remote regions, whereas the Guaymi on the Atlantic side remained in more populated coastal regions. [PARAGRAPH:1] The Spanish first contacted the Guaymi in the early 1500's but attempts to subdue and conquer them largely failed. After a period of armed conflict, Spanish policy resorted to trying to group the Guaymi into settlements controlled by missions. This policy enjoyed only limited success. Some Indians did convert to Christianity and eventually merged with the growing Metiszo community, but most Guaymi retreated further into the remoteness of the mountain rainforests.

TEXT.English: Guaymi
TEXT.German: Guaymi:Guaymi:Guaymi:Guaymi
TEXT.Italian: Guaymi
TEXT.Spanish: Guaymi

TEXT.English: Uracca

[H1]Uracca[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Cacique of the Guaymi[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]Late 1400's -1531[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Urraca was the most famous of three chieftains, the other two being Nata and Parita, all of whom fought against the Spanish conquistadors. He defeated the Spanish several times and in 1522, he achieved the distinction of being the only Indian leader ever force a captain of the Spanish Empire, Diego de Albitez, to sign a peace treaty. [PARAGRAPH:1] After this stunning success, Urraca was subsequently captured by the conquistadors, but he managed to escape, rejoining his people and continuing the fight against the Spanish until his death in 1531.
TEXT.French: [H1]Ourracá[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Cacique des Guaymís[NEWLINE]Dates : [\BOLD]Fin du XVe siècle -1531[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Biographie:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Ourracá était le plus célèbre parmi trois chefs de guerre, les deux autres étant Nata et Parita, qui ont combattu les conquistadors espagnols. Il vainquit les espagnols à plusieurs reprises en 1522. Tant et si bien qu'il fut le premier chef indigène à contraindre un capitaine espagnol, Diego de Albitez, à signer un traité de paix. [PARAGRAPH:1] Après ce grand fait de gloire, Ourracá sera finalement capturé par les conquistadors. Il parvint malgré tout à s'échapper pour rejoindre à nouveau son peuple et reprendre le combat. Il restera invaincu jusqu'à sa mort en 1531.
TEXT.German: [H1]Uracca[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Cacique der Guaymi[NEWLINE]Lebte: [\BOLD]ca. 1490-1531[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Urraca war der bekannteste von drei Häuptlingen, die anderen beiden ware Nata and Parita, die zusammen gegen die spanischen Conquistadores kämpften. Er besiegte die Spanier mehrfach und 1522 schaffte er was noch kein Ureinwohner je zuvor geschafft hatte, er zwang einen Captain des Spanischen Empire, Diego de Albitez, ein Friedensabkommen zu unterzeichnen. [PARAGRAPH:1] Nach diesem erstaunlichen Erfolg wurde Urraca jedoch von den Conquistadores gefanngen genommen, konnte aber entkommen und nahm mit seinem Volk den Kampf gegen die Spanier wieder auf, den er bis zu seinem Tod 1531 fortführte.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Uracca[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Cacique of the Guaymi[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]Late 1400's -1531[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Urraca was the most famous of three chieftains, the other two being Nata and Parita, all of whom fought against the Spanish conquistadors. He defeated the Spanish several times and in 1522, he achieved the distinction of being the only Indian leader ever force a captain of the Spanish Empire, Diego de Albitez, to sign a peace treaty. [PARAGRAPH:1] After this stunning success, Urraca was subsequently captured by the conquistadors, but he managed to escape, rejoining his people and continuing the fight against the Spanish until his death in 1531.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Uracca[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Cacique of the Guaymi[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]Late 1400's -1531[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Urraca was the most famous of three chieftains, the other two being Nata and Parita, all of whom fought against the Spanish conquistadors. He defeated the Spanish several times and in 1522, he achieved the distinction of being the only Indian leader ever force a captain of the Spanish Empire, Diego de Albitez, to sign a peace treaty. [PARAGRAPH:1] After this stunning success, Urraca was subsequently captured by the conquistadors, but he managed to escape, rejoining his people and continuing the fight against the Spanish until his death in 1531.

TEXT.English: My name is [OUR_NAME], and I welcome you to the lands of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] people. Join us in our city to watch the stick throwing games, and tell us about your people.
TEXT.French: Mon nom est [OUR_NAME]. Je vous accueille en terre [OUR_CIV_ADJ:2] en espérant que vous saurez la respecter. Maintenant venez donc assister à nos jeux de lancée de baton, et dites m'en plus sur votre peuple..
TEXT.German: Fremder, ich bin [OUR_NAME], Oberhaupt der Guaymi. Wärmt euch an unseren Feuern, doch achtet die Regeln der Gastfreundschaft.
TEXT.Italian: Salve. Mi chiamo [OUR_NAME], capo e protettore del popolo [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Ti considero un amico. È nel tuo migliore interesse che io non cambi mai idea.
TEXT.Spanish: Hola. Soy [OUR_NAME], jefe y protector del pueblo [OUR_CIV_ADJ:1]. Os considero mis amigos. Y más os vale que nunca cambie de opinión.

TEXT.English: The presence of you cockroaches is a pollution of the rainforest. Leave us alone.
TEXT.French: Vous êtes des cafards qui polluent notre belle forêt tropical. Laissons-nous tranquille.
TEXT.German: Ihr wollt reden, [CT_NAME]? Nein. Handelt lieber und verschwindet aus dieser Welt.
TEXT.Italian: Vuoi parlare? È un po' troppo tardi per farlo.
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Ahora queréis hablar? Es un poco tarde para eso.

TEXT.English: Do you think I'm daft? The only way for the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] to survive is by wiping out every last one of you!
TEXT.French: Vous me prenez pour un abruti ? Les [OUR_CIV_ADJ:3] n'assureront leur survie que le jour où vous serez renvoyés à vos bateaux !
TEXT.German: Nein, Frieden kann es zwischen uns nach euren Taten nicht mehr geben.
TEXT.Italian: Pace? Mai!
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Paz? ¡Jamás!

TEXT.English: The [OUR_CIV_ADJ] welcome the emissaries of the [CT_CIV_ADJ] into their cities. Let us strengthen our friendship and play some games together.
TEXT.French: Les [OUR_CIV_ADJ:3] souhaitent la bienvenue aux émissaires [CT_CV_ADJ:3] dans leurs cités. Renforçons donc notre amitié en s'affrontant dans l'une de nos compétitions.
TEXT.German: Nehmt Platz am Feuer, Freund. Auch wenn Ihr es an Weisheit nicht mit dem großen Urraca aufnehmen könnt, so begegnen wir Euch doch mit Respekt.
TEXT.Italian: È bello avere notizie da [CT_EMPIRE]. A cosa debbo quest'onore?
TEXT.Spanish: Es un placer oír al [CT_EMPIRE]. ¿A qué debo este honor?

TEXT.English: I will waste no words of welcome on you, as you do not have the ability to appreciate them anyway. Why are you bothering us?
TEXT.French: Je ne gâcherais pas ma salive en vous souhaitant la bienvenue. De toute façon, vous n'y voyez aucune valeur. Pourquoi venez-vous nous déranger ?
TEXT.German: Der Große Kriegsrat unseres Volkes berät bereits über Euer weiteres Schicksal, [CT_NAME]. Fügt Euch seinem weisen Ratschluss, und Ihr werdet im Augenblick Eures Todes mehr Würde zeigen als in Eurem ganzen Leben zuvor.
TEXT.Italian: Ti sei avviato lungo un cammino che porterà alla tua distruzione. Prova pure a cercare di spiegarti.
TEXT.Spanish: Habéis hollado una senda que os llevará a la destrucción. Intentad explicaros como queráis.

TEXT.English: My tribe is in need, will the [CT_EMPIRE] prove true friends and help?
TEXT.French: Ma tribu est dans le besoin, l'[CT_EMPIRE] peut-il nous aider ?
TEXT.German: Mein Stamm ist in Not. Teilt Eure Vorräte mit uns, weißer Mann, und unsere Enkel werden ihren Enkeln von Euren milden Taten Geschichten erzählen.
TEXT.Italian: La mia tribù ha bisogno di aiuto, potete aiutarci?
TEXT.Spanish: Mi tribu está necesitada. ¿Podrá ayudarnos el [CT_EMPIRE]?

TEXT.English: I come in peace to ask for assistance. What do you say?
TEXT.French: Je suis venu en paix vous demander de l'aide. Qu'avez-vous à répondre ?
TEXT.German: Ich komme in Frieden und bitte um Unterstützung. Wie lautet Eure Antwort?
TEXT.Italian: Vengo in pace alla ricerca di aiuto. Cosa mi rispondi?
TEXT.Spanish: Vengo en son de paz a pedir ayuda. ¿Qué me decís?

TEXT.English: I could wipe the seed of the [CT_EMPIRE] from this land at will. Give me what I demand and I may allow you to live a while longer.
TEXT.French: Je tiens le destin de l'[CT_EMPIRE] dans ma main. Donnez-moi ce que j'exige.
TEXT.German: Ich halte Euer Schicksal in meinen Händen. Gebt mir, was ich verlange.
TEXT.Italian: Ho nelle mani il destino di [CT_EMPIRE]. Dammi ciò che chiedo.
TEXT.Spanish: Tengo el destino del [CT_EMPIRE] en mis manos. Dadme lo que os exijo.

TEXT.English: Tarascans
TEXT.German: Tarascans:Tarascans:Tarascans

TEXT.English: Tarascans
TEXT.German: Tarascans

TEXT.English: [TAB] The Tarascans were a pre-Columbian civilization whose territory at the time of the Spanish conquest was the second largest state in Mesoamerica. According to the Relacion de Michoacan, a 14th century leader of the P'orhepecha people, named Tariacuri forged the tribes around Lake Patzcuaro into the Tarascan state, placing his sons as overlords to newly acquired territory. Tariacuri died in 1350, but his sons continued their father's work, incorporating the Tarascan Sierra and the Balsas River into the Tarascans expanding sphere of influence. [PARAGRAPH:1] From the mid 15th century until the arrival of the Spanish, the Tarascans found themselves competing against the expanding empire of the Aztecs in a series of wars. The Tarascan empire blocked Aztec expansion to the northwest, fortifying and patrolling their frontiers against attacks from ethnic groups allied with or subjugated to the Aztecs. [PARAGRAPH:1] Hearing of the defeat of the Aztecs, Tangaxuan II, the last Cazonci of the Tarascans, sent emissaries with gifts to the Spanish. Interested by gifts of gold, the Cortes sent a Spanish force under Cristobal de Olid in 1522 to the Tarascan capital of Tzintzuntzan. Tangaxuan submitted to Spanish authority in return for maintaining a large degree of autonomy over his people, and for the next few years both he and the Spanish considered themselves rulers of the empire, with each collecting tribute from the populace. By 1530 the Spanish realized that Tangaxuan was still in effect in control of his empire and dispatched the conquistador Nuno de Guzman to execute him. With the death of Tangaxuan, the Tarascans empire quickly collapsed losing their independence to the Spanish. In 1543 it officially became the governorship of Michoacan.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Le Royaume tarasque était un État mésoaméricain, couvrant à peu près la zone géographique de l'actuel État mexicain de Michoacán. Au moment de la conquête espagnole, il était du point de vue de la superficie et de la puissance militaire le deuxième État de Mésoamérique après l'Empire aztèque. L'État a été fondé au début du XIVe siècle et a perdu son indépendance au profit des Espagnols en 1530. En 1543, il est devenu officiellement l'État du Michoacán, en référence au nom de l'État tarasque en langue nahuatl (« Michoacán » signifie « territoire de ceux qui possèdent des poissons »). En p'urhépecha, la langue des Tarasques, le nom de l'État était « Iréchecua Tzintzuntzáni », qui signifie « les terres de Tzintzuntzan ». [PARAGRAPH:1] Les populations du royaume tarasque appartenaient pour la plupart au groupe ethnique des P'urhépechas, mais elle cohabitaient avec d'autres groupes tels que les peuples Nahua, Otomi, Matlatzinca et chichimèque. Ces groupes ethniques ont été progressivement assimilés par le groupe majoritaire des P'urhépechas. [PARAGRAPH:1] L'État tarasque était constitué d'un réseau de provinces tributaires avant de devenir progressivement de plus en plus centralisé, sous l'autorité du souverain, le Caconzi . La capitale tarasque était située à Tzintzuntzan sur les rives du lac Pátzcuaro, au Michoacán qui, selon la tradition orale tarasque avait été fondé par le premier caconzi Taríacuri et dominé par sa lignée, les Uacúsechas (Aigles en P'urhépecha). [PARAGRAPH:1] L'État tarasque était contemporain de l'Empire aztèque, avec lequel il entretenait des rapports souvent conflictuels. L'empire tarasque a empêché l'expansion aztèque au nord-ouest, et les Tarasques ont du fortifier et surveiller leurs frontières avec leurs voisins, en développant ce qui fut peut-être le premier État véritablement territorial de Mésoamérique. [PARAGRAPH:1] En raison de son relatif isolement au sein de la Mésoamérique, le Royaume tarasque présentait de nombreux traits culturels complètement distincts de ceux des autres groupes culturels mésoaméricains. Il fait partie des quelques civilisations mésoaméricaines à utiliser le métal pour les outils et les ornements.
TEXT.German: [TAB] Die Tarascans waren eine pre-columbianische Zivilisation deren Territorium zur Zeit der Spanischen Eroberung das zweit grösste in Mittelamerika war. Der 'Relacion de Michoacan' zufolge, vereinte im 14ten Jahrhundert ein Führer der P'orhepecha namens Tariacuri die Stämme um den Lake Patzcuaro zum Staat der Tarascans und setzte seinen Sohn als Oberführer des neu erworbenen Gebietes ein. Tariacuri starb 1350, aber sein Sohn setzte seine Arbeit fort und fügte weitere Gebiete der wachsenden Einflussphere hinzu. [PARAGRAPH:1] Ab Mitte des 15ten Jahrhunderts bis zur Ankunft der Spaniern befanden die Tarascans sich in einem Wettstreit um die Vorherrschaft in diesem Gebiet mit den ebenfalls stark expandierenden Imperium der Azteken, der auch in einer Reihe von Kriegen ausgetragen wurde. Die Tarascans blockierten eine weitere Ausdehnung der Azteken in den Nordwesten und befestigten ihre Grenzen gegen ethnische Gruppen, die mit den Azteken verbündet oder von diesen unterworfen waren. [PARAGRAPH:1] Nachdem Tangaxuan II, der letzte Cazonci der Tarascans, von der Niederlange der Azteken gehört hatte, schickte er Abgesandte mit Geschenken zu den Spaniern. Durch die Geschenke aus Gold angelockt, entsandte Cortes 1522 eine spanische Streitmacht untder dem Kommmando von Cristobal de Olid nach Tzintzuntzan, der Hauptstadt der Tarascans. Tangaxuan unterwarf sich der spanischen Authorität um einen teilweise Autonomie für sein Volk erhalten zu können. 1530 erkannten die Spanier, dass Tangaxuan tatsächlich noch die volle Kontrolle über sein Imperium hielt und entsandten den Conquistador Nuno de Guzman um ihn hinzurichten. Mit dem Tod von Tangaxuan kollabierte das Imperium der Tarascans schnell und verlor jegliche Unabhängigkeit an die Spaniern. 1543 wurde es offiziell zum Gouverneursbezirk Michoacan.

TEXT.English: Tarascan
TEXT.German: Tarascan:Tarascan:Tarascan:Tarascan
TEXT.Italian: Tarascan

TEXT.English: Erendira

[H1]Erendira[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Princess of the Tarascans[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]1503-1530?[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Erendira was a princess of the Tarascan people. She was 16 or 17 years old when the Spanish came to Mexico. After the downfall of their enemies the Aztecs, her uncle Tangaxuan II surrendered full autonomy of his kingdom, opting to rule with the Spanish, but was eventually executed by Spanish Conquistadores in 1530.[PARAGRAPH:1] Little is known of Erendira's role during this period, some legends and oral traditions claim that she rallied and led a military force that attacked the Spaniards, and that she personally killed a Conquistador and took his horse, later using the animal to teach her people how to ride, though there is no historical evidence to support this. As in life, Erendira's fate is also shrouded in mystery. Several stories claimed she committed suicide, others that she retreated to the mountains to train her people to fight, and a further story states that she was kidnapped by her own people and put into a temple so that the Spaniards would never find her. The only certainty historians and scholars have is that soon after the fall of the Tarascan empire, Erendiras name disappeared from historical records.
TEXT.French: [H1]Eréndira[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Princesse tarasque[NEWLINE]Dates : [\BOLD]1503-env. 1530[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Biographie :[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Eréndira était une princesse du peuple tarasque. Elle n'avait que 16 ou 17 ans lorsque les espagnols sont arrivés au Mexique. Après la chute de ses ennemis aztècs, son oncle Tangaxuan II a donné tout pouvoir à ses alliés espagnols sur son royaume. Malgré cela, il sera tout de même exécuté par les Conquistadors espagnols en 1530. [PARAGRAPH:1] Nous en savons peu sur le rôle que jouera Eréndira pendant cette période. D'après la tradition orale, elle aurait rassemblé une armée pour attaquer les espagnols. Elle aurait tué de ses propres mains un Conquistador et prit son cheval. Elle aurait ensuite appris à son peuple comment le monter. Il n'y a cependant aucune preuve historique de ces faits de gloire. [PARAGRAPH:1]Nous en savons tout aussi peu sur sa mort. Selon certaines versions elle se serait suicidée ; selon d'autres elles se serait retirée dans les montagnes pour apprendre à son peuple comment combattre. Enfin, selon une dernière version, elle se serait faite enlever par son propre peuple et pour la cacher dans un temple et réduire à néant les chances des espagnols de la retrouver. La seule certitude pour les historiens est que peu de temps après la chute de l'Empire tarasque, le nom d'Eréndira fut effacé des registres historiques.
TEXT.German: [H1]Erendira[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Prinzessin der Tarascans[NEWLINE]Lebte: [\BOLD]1503-1530?[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Erendira war eine Prinzessin des Tarascan Volkes. Sie war 16 oder 17 als die Spanier nach Mexiko kamen. Nach dem Fall ihrer Feinde der Azteken, unterwarf ihr Onkel Tangaxuan II die volle Autonomie des Königreiches an die Spanier in der Hoffnung noch ein wenig Macht zu erhalten. Letztlich wurde er aber durch spanische Conquistadores 1530 hingerichtet.[PARAGRAPH:1] Wenig ist über Erendiras Rolle während dieser Periode bekannt. Einige Legenden und münldiche überlieferungen behaupten aber, dass sie eine Streitmacht versammelte und gegen die Spanier führte. Es wird sogar erzählt, dass sie persönlich eine Conquistador tötete und sein Pferd nahm, um damit später ihrem Volk das Reiten beizubringen. Es gibt jedoch für diese Geschichten keinerlei historische Beweise. Ihr letztes Schicksal ist ebenfalls von Mythen vernebelt. Einige Geschichten erzählen, dass sie Selbstmord beging, andere dass sie in die Berge floh um dort ihr Volk im Kampft auszubilden und wieder andere, dass sie von ihrem Volk in einem Tempel versteckt wurde, damit die Spanier sie niemals finden sollten. Die einzige Gewissheit die Historiker haben ist die, dass kurz nach dem Fall des Tarascan Imperiums auch der Name Erendira in keiner historischen Aufzeichnung mehr auftauchte.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Erendira[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Princess of the Tarascans[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]1503-1530?[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Erendira was a princess of the Tarascan people. She was 16 or 17 years old when the Spanish came to Mexico. After the downfall of their enemies the Aztecs, her uncle Tangaxuan II surrendered full autonomy of his kingdom, opting to rule with the Spanish, but was eventually executed by Spanish Conquistadores in 1530.[PARAGRAPH:1] Little is known of Erendira's role during this period, some legends and oral traditions claim that she rallied and led a military force that attacked the Spaniards, and that she personally killed a Conquistador and took his horse, later using the animal to teach her people how to ride, though there is no historical evidence to support this. As in life, Erendira's fate is also shrouded in mystery. Several stories claimed she committed suicide, others that she retreated to the mountains to train her people to fight, and a further story states that she was kidnapped by her own people and put into a temple so that the Spaniards would never find her. The only certainty historians and scholars have is that soon after the fall of the Tarascan empire, Erendiras name disappeared from historical records.

TEXT.English: The people of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ] Empire greet the visitors from over the sea. I am [OUR_NAME], leader of our many cities. Be warned that we are a strong and proud nation, and do not tolerate disrespect.
TEXT.French: Le peuple de l'Empire [OUR_CIV_ADJ] accueile avec bienveillance ses visiteurs venus des mers. Je suis [OUR_NAME], dirigeant des nombreuses cités [OUR_CIV_ADJ:3]. Soyez prévenus que nous sommes une nation fière et puissante, et que nous ne tolérons pas l'irrespect.
TEXT.German: Fremder, ich bin [OUR_NAME], Oberhaupt der Tarascans. Wärmt euch an unseren Feuern, doch achtet die Regeln der Gastfreundschaft.
TEXT.Italian: Salve. Mi chiamo [OUR_NAME], capo e protettore del popolo [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Ti considero un amico. È nel tuo migliore interesse che io non cambi mai idea.
TEXT.Spanish: Hola. Soy [OUR_NAME], jefe y protector del pueblo [OUR_CIV_ADJ:1]. Os considero mis amigos. Y más os vale que nunca cambie de opinión.

TEXT.English: I'm not willing to talk with someone so vastly inferior in wisdom, strength and honor. Scurry off to the cesspits you use as your living places.
TEXT.French: Je ne souhaite pas parler à quelqu'un d'aussi indigent que vous. Retournez donc dans les huttes qui vous servent d'abri.
TEXT.German: Ihr wollt reden, [CT_NAME]? Nein. Handelt lieber und verschwindet aus dieser Welt.
TEXT.Italian: Vuoi parlare? È un po' troppo tardi per farlo.
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Ahora queréis hablar? Es un poco tarde para eso.

TEXT.English: Does the jaguar ever make peace with the tapir? It is only natural that my warriors continue killing yours.
TEXT.French: Le jaguar a-t-il déjà fait la paix avec le tapir ? Il est dans l'ordre de la nature que le faible périsse.
TEXT.German: Nein, Frieden kann es zwischen uns nach euren Taten nicht mehr geben.
TEXT.Italian: Pace? Mai!
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Paz? ¡Jamás!

TEXT.English: The [OUR_CIV_ADJ] welcome the [CT_CIV_ADJ] in their grand cities. I consider you to be a friend of my people. I trust that our conversation will reflect your ecstasy about having this great honor bestowed upon you.
TEXT.French: Les [OUR_CIV_ADJ:3] souhaitent la bienvenue aux [CT_CIV_ADJ:3]. En tant qu'ami de notre peuple, je vous invite à venir admirer nos grandes villes.
TEXT.German: Nehmt Platz am Feuer, Freund. Auch wenn Ihr es an Weisheit nicht mit der großen Erendira aufnehmen könnt, so begegnen wir Euch doch mit Respekt.
TEXT.Italian: È bello avere notizie da [CT_EMPIRE]. A cosa debbo quest'onore?
TEXT.Spanish: Es un placer oír al [CT_EMPIRE]. ¿A qué debo este honor?

TEXT.English: The beggars of the [CT_EMPIRE] are here again to grovel at my feet. Tell us why you are here, and I may decide to let you leave while still being in possession of the regular number of limbs.
TEXT.French: Les mendiants [CT_CIV_ADJ:3] sont de retours pour me supplier à mes pieds. Dîtes-nous ce que vous voulez ?
TEXT.German: Der Große Kriegsrat unseres Bundes berät bereits über Euer weiteres Schicksal, [CT_NAME]. Fügt Euch seinem weisen Ratschluss, und Ihr werdet im Augenblick Eures Todes mehr Würde zeigen als in Eurem ganzen Leben zuvor.
TEXT.Italian: Ti sei avviato lungo un cammino che porterà alla tua distruzione. Prova pure a cercare di spiegarti.
TEXT.Spanish: Habéis hollado una senda que os llevará a la destrucción. Intentad explicaros como queráis.

TEXT.English: My tribe is in need, will the [CT_EMPIRE] prove true friends and help?
TEXT.French: Ma tribu est dans le besoin, l'[CT_EMPIRE] peut-il nous aider ?
TEXT.German: Mein Stamm ist in Not. Teilt Eure Vorräte mit uns, weißer Mann, und unsere Enkel werden ihren Enkeln von Euren milden Taten Geschichten erzählen.
TEXT.Italian: La mia tribù ha bisogno di aiuto, potete aiutarci?
TEXT.Spanish: Mi tribu está necesitada. ¿Podrá ayudarnos el [CT_EMPIRE]?

TEXT.English: I come in peace to ask for assistance. What do you say?
TEXT.French: Je suis venu en paix vous demander de l'aide. Qu'avez-vous à répondre ?
TEXT.German: Ich komme in Frieden und bitte um Unterstützung. Wie lautet Eure Antwort?
TEXT.Italian: Vengo in pace alla ricerca di aiuto. Cosa mi rispondi?
TEXT.Spanish: Vengo en son de paz a pedir ayuda. ¿Qué me decís?

TEXT.English: I could wipe the seed of the [CT_EMPIRE] from this land at will. Give me what I demand and I may allow you to live a while longer.
TEXT.French: Je tiens le destin de l'[CT_EMPIRE] dans ma main. Donnez-moi ce que j'exige.
TEXT.German: Ich halte Euer Schicksal in meinen Händen. Gebt mir, was ich verlange.
TEXT.Italian: Ho nelle mani il destino di [CT_EMPIRE]. Dammi ciò che chiedo.
TEXT.Spanish: Tengo el destino del [CT_EMPIRE] en mis manos. Dadme lo que os exijo.

TEXT.English: Omagua
TEXT.German: Omagua:Omagua:Omagua

TEXT.English: Omagua
TEXT.German: Omagua

TEXT.English: [TAB] The Omaguas, also known as the Cambeba, were spread in two large groupings within the Amazon Valley. One group occupied the upper Napo and the other the upper Amazon. Until the 17th century the upper Amazon was almost entirely inhabited by the Omagua. [PARAGRAPH:1] The first significant reports of the Omagua, were recorded by Gaspar de Carvajal, a Dominican priest who accompanied Francisco de Orellana's 1542 expedition that traversed the Amazon River. Carvajal reported a populous, organized society whose control extended hundreds of miles along the river, though wrote very little about the people of the Amazon, mostly because they were always trying to kill him. Orellana's party received a cold reception on many parts of the Amazon, particularly from the Machipara and Omaguas, who attacked the Spanish incessantly, killing and wounding several. In order to obtain supplies, Orellana desperately ordered his men to attack their homesteads. On May 21, Orellana and his men passed in front of the entrance to the Madeira river leaving the Machipara and Omagua regions behind them. Orellana died on his second voyage to the Amazon is 1546. [PARAGRAPH:1] Hearing stories of the Omagua's reported wealth, Pedro de Ursua, led an expedition along the Amazon in 1560, only to receive a similar reception that Orellana had twenty years earlier, finding nothing but only further rumors of the fabled city of El dorado. During the 16th and 17th century European introduced diseases led to widespread population collapse amongst the Omagua, leading them to abandoned their cities, and retreat into the rainforest to adopt a more nomadic lifestyle.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Les Omaguas, aussi connus sous le nom de Cambebas, étaient dispersés en deux larges groupes dans la vallée de l'Amazone. L'un occupation le Napo Supérieur et l'autre occupait l'Amazone Supérieur. Jusqu'au XVIIe siècle, l'Amazone supérieur était pratiquement habité exclusivement par les Omaguas. [PARAGRAPH:1] Les premières traces significatives des Omaguas se retrouvent dans les récits de Gaspar de Carvajal, un prêtre dominicain qui accompagna Francisco de Orellana lors de son expédition de 1542 pour remonter le fleuve Amazone. Carvajal mentionna une société organisée, très peuplée, qui contrôlait le territoire le long du fleuve sur des centaines de lieues. Il a cependant très peu écrit sur ce peuple de l'Amazone, ces derniers cherchant avant tout à le tuer. En effet, l'expédition d'Orellana reçut un accueil assez froid des Machiparos, puis des Omaguas, qui ne cessaient de harceler les espagnols. Nombreux d'entre eux furent tués ou blessés. Pour pouvoir se nourrir, Orellana décida d'attaquer leurs villages. Le 21 mai 1542, Orellana et ses hommes passèrent enfin dans le confluent du fleuve Rio Madeira, laissant les régions Machiparos et Omaguas derrière eux. Orellana mourut lors de son second voyage dans l'Amazone en 1546.
TEXT.German: [TAB] Die Omagua, auch als Cambeba bekannt, waren auf zwei grosse Gruppierungen innerhalb des Amazonas Gebietes verteilt. Die eine Gruppe siedelte am oberen Napo und die andere am oberen Amazon. Bis zum 17ten Jahrhundert war der obere Amazonas fast vollständig durch die Omagua besiedelt. [PARAGRAPH:1] Die ersten signifikanten Berichte über die Omagua wurden von Gaspar de Carvajal, einem Dominikanischen Priester, aufgezeichnet, der 1542 die Expedition von Francisco de Orellana begleitete, die entlang des Amazonas reiste. Carvajal berichtete von einer bevölkerungsreichen und organisierten Gesellschaft, die hunderte von Meilen entlang des Amazonas kontrollierte, schrieb jedoch sehr wenig über die Menschen des Amazonas selbst, was hauptsächlich daran lag, dass diese versuchten ihn zu töten. Orellanas Gruppe erhielt einen eisigen Empfang durch die Omagua, die unaufhörlich die Spanier angriffenund viele töteten oder verwundeten. Um Vorräte zu erhalten befahl Orellana seinen Männern in seiner Verzweiflung die Dörfer dieser Ureinwohner anzugreifen. Am 21. Mai 1542 passierte Orellana den Mündung des Madeira und lies die Machipara und Omagua Gebiete hinter sich. Orellana starb 1546 bei seiner zweiten Reise in den Amazonas.[PARAGRAPH:1] Pedro de Ursua, der Geschichten über den Reichtum der Omagua gehört hatte, führte 1560 eine weitere Expedition entlang des Amazonas. Ausser Gerüchten über die mystische Stadt El Dorado fand er nichts.[PARAGRAPH:1] Im 16ten und 17ten Jahrhundert führte Krankheiten, die durch die Europäer eingeschleppt worden waren zu einem Bevölkerungskollaps unter den Omagua, worauf diese ihre Städte verliesen, in den Regenwald flohen und einen nomadischen Lebensstil annahmen.

Until the 17th century the upper Amazon was almost entirely inhabited by the Omagua. [PARAGRAPH:1] The first significant reports of the Omagua, were recorded by Gaspar de Carvajal, a Dominican priest who accompanied Francisco de Orellana's 1542 expedition that traversed the Amazon River. Carvajal reported a populous, organized society whose control extended hundreds of miles along the river, though wrote very little about the people of the Amazon, mostly because they were always trying to kill him. Orellana's party received a cold reception on many parts of the Amazon, particularly from the Machipara and Omaguas, who attacked the Spanish incessantly, killing and wounding several. In order to obtain supplies, Orellana desperately ordered his men to attack their homesteads. On May 21, Orellana and his men passed in front of the entrance to the Madeira river leaving the Machipara and Omagua regions behind them. Orellana died on his second voyage to the Amazon is 1546. [PARAGRAPH:1] Hearing stories of the Omagua's reported wealth, Pedro de Ursua, led an expedition along the Amazon in 1560, only to receive a similar reception that Orellana had twenty years earlier, finding nothing but only further rumors of the fabled city of El dorado. During the 16th and 17th century European introduced diseases led to widespread population collapse amongst the Omagua, leading them to abandoned their cities, and retreat into the rainforest to adopt a more nomadic lifestyle.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB] The Omaguas, also known as the Cambeba, were spread in two large groupings within the Amazon Valley. One group occupied the upper Napo and the other the upper Amazon. Until the 17th century the upper Amazon was almost entirely inhabited by the Omagua. [PARAGRAPH:1] The first significant reports of the Omagua, were recorded by Gaspar de Carvajal, a Dominican priest who accompanied Francisco de Orellana's 1542 expedition that traversed the Amazon River. Carvajal reported a populous, organized society whose control extended hundreds of miles along the river, though wrote very little about the people of the Amazon, mostly because they were always trying to kill him. Orellana's party received a cold reception on many parts of the Amazon, particularly from the Machipara and Omaguas, who attacked the Spanish incessantly, killing and wounding several. In order to obtain supplies, Orellana desperately ordered his men to attack their homesteads. On May 21, Orellana and his men passed in front of the entrance to the Madeira river leaving the Machipara and Omagua regions behind them. Orellana died on his second voyage to the Amazon is 1546. [PARAGRAPH:1] Hearing stories of the Omagua's reported wealth, Pedro de Ursua, led an expedition along the Amazon in 1560, only to receive a similar reception that Orellana had twenty years earlier, finding nothing but only further rumors of the fabled city of El dorado. During the 16th and 17th century European introduced diseases led to widespread population collapse amongst the Omagua, leading them to abandoned their cities, and retreat into the rainforest to adopt a more nomadic lifestyle.

TEXT.English: Omagua
TEXT.German: Omagua:Omagua:Omagua:Omagua
TEXT.Italian: Omagua
TEXT.Spanish: Omagua

TEXT.English: Aomagua

[H1]Aomagua[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Cacique of the Omagua[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]Early to mid 16th century[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Little is known of any individual Omagua cacique. The expeditions of Orellana and Ursua, rarely mentioned the names of native individuals, and when they did they often confused the name of the tribe with that of the village and its leader. Thus the leader of the Omagua is often referred to as Aomagua. [PARAGRAPH:1] Aomagua ordered several waves of attacks against the Spanish under Orellana in an attempt to wear the Spanish down and defeat them. His attempts were not successful but the incessant hostility the Omagua dealt the Spanish, was enough to convince Orellana to move swiftly through their territory. It was probably warriors from one of the Omagua tribes who displaying long hair and bone earrings, were likely mistaken as women warriors, fueling the story that would eventually give the region its name, Amazon, after the Greek legend.
TEXT.French: [H1]Aomagua[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Cacique des Omaguas[NEWLINE]Dates : [\BOLD]Première moitié du XVIe siècle[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Biographie :[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Nous en savons très peu sur les caciques omaguas. Les expéditions d'Orellana et d'Ursua ont rarement fait référence à des personnages indigènes en particulier, et lorsque ce fut le cas, ils confondaient très régulièrement les noms des villages et ceux de leur chef. C'est la raison pour laquelle nous nous souvenons du cacique omagua sous le nom de Aomagua. [PARAGRAPH:1] Nous savons cependant de source sûre que Aomagua est à l'origine des raids incessants subis par l'expédition espagnole d'Orellana pour l'inciter à rebrousser chemin. Cette tentative se révélera infructueuse mais elle était suffisamment convaincante pour qu'Orellana ne traîne pas trop longtemps sur son territoire. L'expédition d'Ursua vingt années plus tard eu droit au même accueil. Il est impossible de savoir si Aomagua était encore en vie à cette époque.
TEXT.German: [H1]Aomagua[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Cacique der Omagua[NEWLINE]Lebte: [\BOLD]Mitte des 16ten Jahrhunderts[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB]Wenig ist über einzelne Cacique der Omagua bekannt. Die Expeditionen von Orellana und Ursua, nannten kaum Namen einzelner Individuen, und falls doch wurden oft Namen von Stämmen mit Ortschaften oder deren Anführern durcheinander gebracht. Daher wird der Anführer der Omagua oft als Aomagua bezeichnet. [PARAGRAPH:1] Es ist jedoch bekannt, dass der Aomagua mehrere Angriffswellen gegen die Spanier unter Orellana befahl, um die Spanier aufzureiben und letztlich zu besiegen. Seine Anstrengungen waren nicht erfolgreich aber die fortwährende Aggression war genug, um die Orellana zu überzeugen schnellstmöglich das Territorium zu durchqueren. Es waren vermutlich die Omagua, die mit ihrem langen Haar und den Knochenohrringen leicht für Frauenkriegerinnen gehalten werden konnten, die den Amazonas aufgrund der griechischen Legende weiblicher Kriegerinnen den Namen gaben.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Aomagua[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Cacique of the Omagua[NEWLINE]Lived: [\BOLD]Early to mid 16th century[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][TAB] Little is known of any individual Omagua cacique. The expeditions of Orellana and Ursua, rarely mentioned the names of native individuals, and when they did they often confused the name of the tribe with that of the village and its leader. Thus the leader of the Omagua is often referred to as Aomagua. [PARAGRAPH:1] Aomagua ordered several waves of attacks against the Spanish under Orellana in an attempt to wear the Spanish down and defeat them. His attempts were not successful but the incessant hostility the Omagua dealt the Spanish, was enough to convince Orellana to move swiftly through their territory. It was probably warriors from one of the Omagua tribes who displaying long hair and bone earrings, were likely mistaken as women warriors, fueling the story that would eventually give the region its name, Amazon, after the Greek legend.

His attempts were not successful but the incessant hostility the Omagua dealt the Spanish, was enough to convince Orellana to move swiftly through their territory. TEXT.English: I, [OUR_NAME], represent the prosperous and wealthy nation of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Join me in a banquet together with the nobles of my people, and you will see that peace and cooperation between our nations will benefit us both.
TEXT.French: Moi, [OUR_NAME], représente la nation prospère et riche des [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Rejoignez-moi pour un banquet avec les nobles de mon peuple, et vous verrez qu'une coopération entre nos deux nations peut nous être mutuellement bénéfiques.
TEXT.German: Fremder, ich bin [OUR_NAME], Oberhaupt der Omagua. Wärmt euch an unseren Feuern, doch achtet die Regeln der Gastfreundschaft.
TEXT.Italian: Salve. Mi chiamo [OUR_NAME], capo e protettore del popolo [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Ti considero un amico. È nel tuo migliore interesse che io non cambi mai idea.
TEXT.Spanish: Hola. Soy [OUR_NAME], jefe y protector del pueblo [OUR_CIV_ADJ:1]. Os considero mis amigos. Y más os vale que nunca cambie de opinión.

TEXT.English: We do not speak with traitors. Deadlier than your diseases are your words.
TEXT.French: Nous ne parlons pas avec les traîtres. Vos paroles sont plus mortelles encore que vos maladies.
TEXT.German: Ihr wollt reden, [CT_NAME]? Nein. Handelt lieber und verschwindet aus dieser Welt.
TEXT.Italian: Vuoi parlare? È un po' troppo tardi per farlo.
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Ahora queréis hablar? Es un poco tarde para eso.

TEXT.English: Peace is not in the interests of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Ensuring that you cannot repeat your past crimes, however, is.
TEXT.French: La paix n'est pas dans l'intérêt des [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. S'assurer que vous n'aurez plus l'occasion de répéter vos crimes passés l'est davantage.
TEXT.German: Nein, Frieden kann es zwischen uns nach euren Taten nicht mehr geben.
TEXT.Italian: Pace? Mai!
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Paz? ¡Jamás!

TEXT.English: Welcome to the grand jungles of the [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Let us speak of the prosperity that has resulted from our friendship. Please enjoy our hospitality during your stay.
TEXT.French: Bienvenue en jungle [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. C'est une joie de vous revoir. Profitez de notre hospitalité pendant votre séjour.
TEXT.German: Nehmt Platz am Feuer, Freund. Auch wenn Ihr es an Weisheit nicht mit dem großen Aomagua aufnehmen könnt, so begegnen wir Euch doch mit Respekt.
TEXT.Italian: È bello avere notizie da [CT_EMPIRE]. A cosa debbo quest'onore?
TEXT.Spanish: Es un placer oír al [CT_EMPIRE]. ¿A qué debo este honor?

TEXT.English: Not you again. If you only had never come to these lands, and left us in peace! What is it this time?
TEXT.French: Oh non encore vous ! Si seulement vous n'aviez jamais mis le pied dans ce pays ! Que voulez-vous encore ?
TEXT.German: Der Große Kriegsrat unseres Bundes berät bereits über Euer weiteres Schicksal, [CT_NAME]. Fügt Euch seinem weisen Ratschluss, und Ihr werdet im Augenblick Eures Todes mehr Würde zeigen als in Eurem ganzen Leben zuvor.
TEXT.Italian: Ti sei avviato lungo un cammino che porterà alla tua distruzione. Prova pure a cercare di spiegarti.
TEXT.Spanish: Habéis hollado una senda que os llevará a la destrucción. Intentad explicaros como queráis.

TEXT.English: My tribe is in need, will the [CT_EMPIRE] prove true friends and help?
TEXT.French: Ma tribu est dans le besoin, l'[CT_EMPIRE] peut-il nous aider ?
TEXT.German: Mein Stamm ist in Not. Teilt Eure Vorräte mit uns, weißer Mann, und unsere Enkel werden ihren Enkeln von Euren milden Taten Geschichten erzählen.
TEXT.Italian: La mia tribù ha bisogno di aiuto, potete aiutarci?
TEXT.Spanish: Mi tribu está necesitada. ¿Podrá ayudarnos el [CT_EMPIRE]?

TEXT.English: I come in peace to ask for assistance. What do you say?
TEXT.French: Je suis venu en paix vous demander de l'aide. Qu'avez-vous à répondre ?
TEXT.German: Ich komme in Frieden und bitte um Unterstützung. Wie lautet Eure Antwort?
TEXT.Italian: Vengo in pace alla ricerca di aiuto. Cosa mi rispondi?
TEXT.Spanish: Vengo en son de paz a pedir ayuda. ¿Qué me decís?

TEXT.English: I could wipe the seed of the [CT_EMPIRE] from this land at will. Give me what I demand and I may allow you to live a while longer.
TEXT.French: Je tiens le destin de l'[CT_EMPIRE] dans ma main. Donnez-moi ce que j'exige.
TEXT.German: Ich halte Euer Schicksal in meinen Händen. Gebt mir, was ich verlange.
TEXT.Italian: Ho nelle mani il destino di [CT_EMPIRE]. Dammi ciò che chiedo.
TEXT.Spanish: Tengo el destino del [CT_EMPIRE] en mis manos. Dadme lo que os exijo.

TEXT.English: Mapuche
TEXT.German: Mapuche:Mapuche:Mapuche

TEXT.English: Mapuche
TEXT.German: Mapuche

TEXT.English: [TAB] The Mapuche are a tribe that originally inhabited parts of present day south-central Chile and southwestern Argentina. Despite a lack of centralized organization, the Mapuche were successful in resisting attempts to subjugate them from their much larger neighbor to the north, the Inca. [PARAGRAPH:1] After the conquest of Chile by the Spanish in the late 16thcentury, the Mapuche continued to successfully repel Spanish incursions into their territory, for nearly 300 years using the natural geographical boundary of the Bio-Bio River to assist them. During this period of Mapuche resistance, the Mapuche often fluctuated between periods of fighting and trading with the Spanish and Chileans. [PARAGRAPH:1] By the late 18th century, many Mapuche leaders had finally come to accept the sovereignty of the Spanish king, but with the understanding that they continued to retain de facto control and independence over their own people and territory. During the Chilean War of Independence, 1810-26, Mapuche leaders sided with both the Spanish and the Chileans, playing each side against the other to gain the most favorable advantage for themselves, though most looked on the war with indifference. After the Chileans gained Independence, the Mapuche for the most part in Araucania and Patagonia remained autonomous until the Chilean Occupation of Araucania and the Argentine Conquest of the Desert in late 19th century, when they were removed to reservations.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Les Mapuches, littéralement « Peuple de la terre » en mapudungun, sont les communautés aborigènes de la zone centre-sud du Chili et de l'Argentine, connues également sous le nom d'Araucans. [PARAGRAPH:1] Originaires des Andes chiliennes, ils ont propagé leur culture aux tribus het et tehuelches, de la Pampa à la Patagonie argentine, entre le XVIIIe et le XIXe siècles. Ni les Incas ni les Conquistadors ne réussirent à les soumettre. Cette résistance a inspiré le fameux poème épique La Araucana3 (1569, 1578 et en 1589) d'Alonso de Ercilla. [PARAGRAPH:1] La résistance de Lautaro, qui apprit la tactique et la stratégie militaires lorsqu'il était prisonnier des Espagnols, et plus tard la rébellion de Pelantaro en 1602, ont fixé la frontière militaire entre Espagnols et Mapuches au niveau de la rivière Biobío. Dès lors, les Espagnols hésitèrent à se risquer en territoire mapuche. [PARAGRAPH:1] Vers 1880, l'Argentine et le Chili entreprirent des guerres de conquête contre les Indiens (Mapuches et Patagons) qui vivaient au sud du continent dans des régions incontrôlées et difficilement pénétrables. Ces guerres, dont la « conquête du Désert » du général Julio Argentino Roca, qui firent des dizaines de milliers de morts parmi les Indiens, poursuivaient aussi un autre objectif : l'accès aux deux océans. Le Chili voulait s'ouvrir sur l'Atlantique par le sud et l'Argentine sur le Pacifique, là aussi par le sud. Finalement, la frontière fut stabilisée dans sa forme actuelle à la fin du XIXe siècle.
TEXT.German: [TAB] Die Mapuche sind ein Stamm, der ursprünglich Teile des heutigen Chile und südwestlichen Argentinien bewohnte. Trotz des Fehlens einer zentralen Organisation waren die Mapuche erfolgreich darin, sich gegen eine Unterwerfung durch ihre viel grösseren Nachbarn die Inka zu wehren. [PARAGRAPH:1] Nach der Eroberung Chiles durch die Spanier im späten 16ten Jahrhundert fuhren die Mapuche 300 Jahre erfolgreich damit fort das spanische Eindringen in ihr Territorium abzuwehren. In dieser Periode fluktuierte die Beziehung der Mapuche zu den Spaniern und Chilenen oft zwischen Kampf und Handel. [PARAGRAPH:1] Im späten 18ten Jahrhundert hatte viele Anführer der Mapuche letztlich die Oberherrschaft des spanischen Königs anerkannt, behielten aber das Verständnis bei, dass sie de facto weiterhin die Kontrolle über ihr Volk und ihre Territorien inne hielen. Im Chilenischen Unabhängigkeitskrieg 1810-26 unterstützen Mapuche Anführer beide Seiten, die Spanier, wie auch die Chilenen, spieleten diese gegeneinander aus und suchten ihre eigenen Vorteile. Nach der Unabhängigkeit Chiles, blieben die Mapuche, die hauptsächlich in Araucania und Patagonia lebten, weitgehend autonom. Dies änderte sich erst durch die Chilenische Unterdrückung und die Argentinische Eroberung im späten 19ten Jahrhundert, als sie in Reservate umgesiedelt wurden.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB] The Mapuche are a tribe that originally inhabited parts of present day south-central Chile and southwestern Argentina. Despite a lack of centralized organization, the Mapuche were successful in resisting attempts to subjugate them from their much larger neighbor to the north, the Inca. [PARAGRAPH:1] After the conquest of Chile by the Spanish in the late 16thcentury, the Mapuche continued to successfully repel Spanish incursions into their territory, for nearly 300 years using the natural geographical boundary of the Bio-Bio River to assist them. During this period of Mapuche resistance, the Mapuche often fluctuated between periods of fighting and trading with the Spanish and Chileans. [PARAGRAPH:1] By the late 18th century, many Mapuche leaders had finally come to accept the sovereignty of the Spanish king, but with the understanding that they continued to retain de facto control and independence over their own people and territory. During the Chilean War of Independence, 1810-26, Mapuche leaders sided with both the Spanish and the Chileans, playing each side against the other to gain the most favorable advantage for themselves, though most looked on the war with indifference. After the Chileans gained Independence, the Mapuche for the most part in Araucania and Patagonia remained autonomous until the Chilean Occupation of Araucania and the Argentine Conquest of the Desert in late 19th century, when they were removed to reservations.

Despite a lack of centralized organization, the Mapuche were successful in resisting attempts to subjugate them from their much larger neighbor to the north, the Inca. [PARAGRAPH:1] After the conquest of Chile by the Spanish in the late 16thcentury, the Mapuche continued to successfully repel Spanish incursions into their territory, for nearly 300 years using the natural geographical boundary of the Bio-Bio River to assist them. During this period of Mapuche resistance, the Mapuche often fluctuated between periods of fighting and trading with the Spanish and Chileans. [PARAGRAPH:1] By the late 18th century, many Mapuche leaders had finally come to accept the sovereignty of the Spanish king, but with the understanding that they continued to retain de facto control and independence over their own people and territory. During the Chilean War of Independence, 1810-26, Mapuche leaders sided with both the Spanish and the Chileans, playing each side against the other to gain the most favorable advantage for themselves, though most looked on the war with indifference. After the Chileans gained Independence, the Mapuche for the most part in Araucania and Patagonia remained autonomous until the Chilean Occupation of Araucania and the Argentine Conquest of the Desert in late 19th century, when they were removed to reservations.
